![](image)Progression of the record for most F1 Grand Prix wins
![](image)Seven-time World Drivers' Champion Michael Schumacher held the record for the most Grand Prix victories with 91, before being surpassed by Lewis Hamilton in 2020.
![](image)Sebastian Vettel currently has four consecutive titles to his name, winning them all with Red Bull Racing.
![](image)Four-time World Champion Alain Prost driving his McLaren MP4-2B in 1985
![](image)Ayrton Senna won the Canadian Grand Prix in 1988.
![](image)George Russell is the 113th and latest first-time Grand Prix winner, having taken victory at the 2022 S√£o Paulo Grand Prix.
## By nationality[edit]


</fragment>
<fragment>

As of the 2023 Las Vegas Grand Prix, out of the 775 drivers who started a Grand Prix,[14] there have been 113 Formula One Grand Prix winners.[15] The first Grand Prix winner was Giuseppe Farina at the 1950 British Grand Prix, and the most recent driver to score their first Grand Prix win is George Russell who took his first win at the 2022 S√£o Paulo Grand Prix.[15] Three Grands Prix, the 1951 French, the 1956 Argentine and the 1957 British Grand Prix, were won by two drivers sharing a car.[16]


This list includes the winners of the Indianapolis 500 race between 1950 and 1960, as they formed part of the World Championships, even though they were not run by Formula One regulations, nor are they referred to as Grands Prix.[17]

He won his first Grand Prix at the 2003 Malaysian Grand Prix, and his last at the 2018 United States Grand Prix, a span of 15¬†years and 212¬†days.[8] Riccardo Patrese holds the record for the longest period of time between two race wins ‚Äì more than six-and-a-half years between the 1983 South African Grand Prix and the 1990 San Marino Grand Prix.[9] Mario Andretti had to wait the longest time between his maiden victory at the 1971 South African Grand Prix and his second win ‚Äì coming five years, seven months and 18 days later at the 1976 Japanese Grand Prix.[10] Max Verstappen holds the record for the most consecutive wins, having won ten Grands Prix in a row in 2023.[11] Verstappen is also the youngest winner of a Grand Prix; he was 18 years and 228 days old when he won the 2016 Spanish Grand Prix.[12] Luigi Fagioli is the oldest winner of a Formula One Grand Prix; he was 53¬†years and 22¬†days old when he won the 1951 French Grand Prix.[13]

### Number of wins at different circuits[edit]


</fragment>
<fragment>
Hamilton has been most successful at the Hungaroring and the Silverstone Circuit,[3] where he has won eight times each, sharing the record with Schumacher for the most victories at the same race track and the same Grand Prix, the British and Hungarian Grands Prix.[17][18] He also holds the record for winning the most different Grands Prix and race tracks at 31 each,[19][20] and shares the record for the most consecutive seasons with at least one victory with Schumacher at 15 years in succession.[21] Hamilton's largest margin of victory was at the rain-affected 2008 British Grand Prix, a race in which he finished 68.577 seconds ahead of BMW Sauber's second-placed finisher Nick Heidfeld,[22][23] while the narrowest margin was at the 2016 Abu Dhabi Grand Prix, where he won by 0.439 seconds over Rosberg as he slowed in an unsuccessful attempt to allow other drivers to catch and pass his teammate in one last attempt to win that year's title.[23][24]

### Number of wins at different Grands Prix[edit]

<fragment>

Hamilton has won at a record 31 out of 38 different circuits at which he has driven.[20][129] The seven race tracks where Hamilton has not won a Grand Prix are the Buddh International Circuit, the Circuit de Nevers Magny-Cours, Circuit Zandvoort, the Korea International Circuit, the Las Vegas Strip Circuit, the Miami International Autodrome and the Valencia Street Circuit.[129]

Lewis Hamilton is a British racing driver who has won seven Formula One World Championships.[1] He made his Formula One debut with the McLaren team in 2007, achieving his first career victory in that year's Canadian Grand Prix from his maiden pole position in only his sixth Grand Prix start.[2] Hamilton achieved three more victories that season,[3] becoming the second rookie after Jacques Villeneuve to be World Drivers' Championship runner-up, and equalled Villeneuve's record of most Grand Prix wins in his debut season.[4] The following year, he won five Grands Prix,[a] becoming, at 23 years and 300 days, the youngest driver to win the World Drivers' Championship at the time following a last-lap overtake on Timo Glock at the final round of the season, the wet-weather affected Brazilian Grand Prix.[b][7][8] The next four seasons saw Hamilton unable to match his championship-winning performances, achieving two victories in 2009,

<fragment>
Hamilton has been most successful at the Hungaroring and the Silverstone Circuit,[3] where he has won eight times each, sharing the record with Schumacher for the most victories at the same race track and the same Grand Prix, the British and Hungarian Grands Prix.[17][18] He also holds the record for winning the most different Grands Prix and race tracks at 31 each,[19][20] and shares the record for the most consecutive seasons with at least one victory with Schumacher at 15 years in succession.[21] Hamilton's largest margin of victory was at the rain-affected 2008 British Grand Prix, a race in which he finished 68.577 seconds ahead of BMW Sauber's second-placed finisher Nick Heidfeld,[22][23] while the narrowest margin was at the 2016 Abu Dhabi Grand Prix, where he won by 0.439 seconds over Rosberg as he slowed in an unsuccessful attempt to allow other drivers to catch and pass his teammate in one last attempt to win that year's title.[23][24]

Hamilton has won at a record 31 out of 39 different Grands Prix in which he has competed.[19][128] The 70th Anniversary Grand Prix, the Dutch Grand Prix, the European Grand Prix, the Indian Grand Prix, the Korean Grand Prix, the Las Vegas Grand Prix, the Mexico City Grand Prix and the Miami Grand Prix are the eight races he has entered and not won.[128]

<fragment>

Hamilton has won at a record 31 out of 38 different circuits at which he has driven.[20][129] The seven race tracks where Hamilton has not won a Grand Prix are the Buddh International Circuit, the Circuit de Nevers Magny-Cours, Circuit Zandvoort, the Korea International Circuit, the Las Vegas Strip Circuit, the Miami International Autodrome and the Valencia Street Circuit.[129]






</fragment>
<fragment>
breaking Schumacher's record of 91 for the most career Grand Prix victories.[14] He won eight more races in 2021 but did not become World Champion,[12][13] however, that season saw him become the first driver to achieve 100 victories when he won the Russian Grand Prix.[15] The 2022 season was the first in his career in which he did not win a race.[16]
